CARDINAL . On DATE , while the Secretary of ORG was considering the applicant ’s representations , the Attorney - General ’s Department of ORG provided the following information on the applicant ’s likely sentence :

“ While it is possible , given the seriousness of the offences , that PERSON may receive a sentence of life imprisonment , the sentencing ORG is required to set a nonparole period unless , having regard to the nature and circumstances of the offence and to the antecedents of the person , the ORG is satisfied that it is not appropriate to fix a non - parole period . CARDINAL . On DATE the Secretary of ORG ordered the applicant ’s extradition to GPE . NORP In reply to the complaint about the likely imposition of a life sentence in the event of conviction , it was noted that it would be highly unusual for NORP courts not to fix a non - parole period , and , in any event , it would not be unjust or oppressive to return the applicant to GPE purely on the basis of the sentence he could receive if convicted of serious criminal offences . As to the argument that the applicant would be unable to plead duress in GPE , no evidence had been submitted to substantiate the claims of intimidation of the applicant and his family or that these mattes were reported to the police . The NORP authorities had confirmed that should any of the applicant ’s witnesses be subjected to threats , appropriate action would be taken by the NORP police . They also advised that it was open to the applicant to apply for a suppression order in relation to the names of any witnesses who feared for their safety . If his witnesses were unable or unwilling to attend trial in GPE he could apply to the NORP courts for evidence to be given via video link . It was also possible for evidence not requiring crossexamination to be submitted in the form of a written statement . On this basis , the Secretary of ORG was satisfied that there was sufficient provision to allow the applicant ’s witnesses to give evidence to the NORP courts and there would be no breach of his rights under LAW ( d ) . As to the LAW complaint the applicant ’s family circumstances were not so exceptional as to engage this provision . In addition , GPE was obliged to fulfil its international obligations towards its extradition partner . The applicant ’s co - accused had already been tried in GPE , and , as such , it would not be unreasonable for the NORP authorities to expect related trials to be conducted in the same jurisdiction .

CARDINAL . The applicant then made further representations , arguing that there would be a further breach of LAW since he would not obtain legal aid in GPE . He renewed his representations on DATE and also claimed that the NORP provisions governing the transfer of prisoners were discriminatory and were applied inconsistently and arbitrarily .

CARDINAL . These further representations were rejected by the Secretary of ORG on DATE . As to the legal aid complaint the NORP authorities had confirmed that persons charged with serious criminal offences would normally be granted legal aid if their means were insufficient to engage private legal representatives . If the applicant were to be refused legal aid , he could make an application for a stay of the trial : the relevant NORP case - law ( PERSON v. the Queen ( DATE ORG CARDINAL ) ) provided that where an accused charged with a serious offence , who through no fault on his or her part was unable to obtain legal representation , applied to the trial judge for an adjournment or stay then , in the absence of exceptional circumstances , the trial should be adjourned , postponed , or stayed , until legal representation was available . If an application that the trial be delayed was refused , and by reason of the lack of representation of the accused , the resulting trial was not a fair one , any conviction of the accused would have to be quashed by an appellate court for the reason that there had been a miscarriage of justice in that the accused had been convicted without a fair trial . Further , the Secretary of ORG noted that the applicant ’s co - accused had been granted legal aid for their trials in GPE .

CARDINAL . As to the applicant ’s contention concerning the NORP provisions for the transfer of sentenced prisoners , GPE was a party to the multilateral ORG on ORG , which was incorporated into NORP domestic law . The applicant , if convicted , would be eligible to apply for transfer . The Secretary of ORG was satisfied that any application for transfer he might wish to make would receive appropriate and fair consideration . On DATE , the Secretary of ORG again found the applicant ’s circumstances were not so exceptional as to prevent extradition .

CARDINAL . On DATE the High Court refused permission for judicial review . It refused to interfere with the Secretary of ORG ’s finding that GPE was the appropriate venue for the trial , especially when the alleged co - conspirators had been tried there . On the fairness of the trial in GPE , Lord Justice PERSON ( with whom PERSON Justice PERSON agreed ) accepted that the legal aid authorities in GPE would not fund the travel of defence witnesses but this was remedied by the fact that there was no bar on witnesses giving evidence by video link . He added :

“ However more importantly , the evidence before this court simply does not raise a scintilla of a suggestion that the NORP judicial authorities will permit a trial to proceed if to do so would be unjust to the applicant . The case of PERSON has been cited by the NORP authorities to the Secretary of ORG , who has considered it . As one would expect of NORP jurisprudence , it essentially says that if there is unfairness to a defendant arising out of difficulties from legal aid funding , the court will be astute to exercise such powers as it has to ensure that the trial is ultimately a fair trial or is stayed . I can therefore see no justification for concluding that there will be any breach of LAW in the Secretary of ORG ’s decision to return the appellant to GPE . ”

CARDINAL . At the relevant time , extradition arrangements between GPE and GPE were governed by LAW DATE . By section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the LAW , the Secretary of ORG has a general discretion to order a person ’s surrender , including when it would , having regard to all the circumstances , be unjust or oppressive to return the person .
